text.headline:
Aston Villa F.C.
History
text.text: Aston Villa is a professional football club based in Witton, Birmingham, that plays in the Premier League, the highest level of English football. Founded in 1874, they have played at their current home ground, Villa Park, since 1897. Aston Villa were the originators and founder members of the Football League in 1888.

text.headline: Humble Beginnings
text.text: Jack Hughes, Frederick Matthews, Walter Price and William Scattergood from the Villa Cross Wesleyan Chapel cricket team meet under a gas-light to form a new club.

text.headline: FA Cup win
text.text: Villa triumph in the FA Cup with a 2-0 victory against West Brom in front of some 15,000 spectators.

text.headline: Football League founded
text.text: Villa director William McGregor pioneers the formation of the first Football League by calling the country’s leading clubs together.

text.headline: League Title win
text.text: First League Championship triumph followed by a second FA Cup triumph the following term.

text.headline: FA Cup stolen
text.text: The FA Cup trophy stolen from a Birmingham shop window where it had been on display.

text.headline: League Title win
text.text: Villa are champions for a second time in three years.

text.headline: League Title win and move to Villa Park
text.text: Villa move from Perry Barr to Villa Park. The Villans take the league title by 11 points and secure the double by beating three top quality sides to carry off the FA Cup.

text.headline: League Title win
text.text: A dramatic league season as Villa beat rivals Liverpool 5-0 on the final day to again lift the trophy.

text.headline: League Title win
text.text: Villa retain their league title.

text.headline: FA Cup win
text.text: Villa, once again, capture the FA Cup with Harry Hampton scoring two goals against Newcastle United in front of 101,117.

text.headline: League Title win
text.text: Villa win their sixth league title.

text.headline: Villa Park bought
text.text: Villa buy Villa Park.

text.headline: FA Cup win
text.text: Villa win the FA Cup for a record-equalling fifth time, beating Sunderland 1-0.

text.headline: FA Cup win
text.text: Villa yet again triumph in the FA Cup, beating favourites Huddersfield in the final.

text.headline: 49 League goals for Waring
text.text: Tom ‘Pongo’ Waring scores an amazing 49 league goals as Villa finish runners-up to Arsenal in the league.

text.headline: FA Cup win
text.text: Eric Houghton’s Villa triumph in the FA Cup of 1957, beating Manchester United 2-1 in the final.

text.headline: League Cup win
text.text: Villa win the newly created League Cup, beating Rotherham United over two legs.

text.headline: League Cup win
text.text: Villa win the League Cup with a 1-0 win over Norwich, Ray Graydon scoring the winning goal from a penalty rebound.

text.headline: League Cup win
text.text: Villa beat Everton 3-2 at Old Trafford to win the League Cup yet again after 2 replays. The first match at Wembley finishes goalless, followed by a 1-1 draw at Hillsborough.

text.headline: League Title win
text.text: Villa win the League Championship under the stewardship of Ron Saunders.

text.headline: European Cup win
text.text: Tony Barton guides Villa into their first European Cup final. Peter Withe scores the winning goal against Bayern Munich in the final.

text.headline: Doug Ellis takes over
text.text: Doug Ellis returns to Villa Park as chairman.

text.headline: Division Two win
text.text: The claret and blue troops hold out for a point on the last day of the season to go back up to Division One.

text.headline: League Cup win
text.text: Villa win another League Cup, with Ron Atkinson’s men running out 3-1 winners over Manchester United.

text.headline: League Cup win
text.text: Brian Little leads Villa to another League Cup final victory over Leeds United, winning 3-0.

text.headline: FA Cup runners-up
text.text: Villa reach the FA Cup final at Wembley but go down 1-0 to Chelsea.

text.headline: O'Neill and Lerner join
text.text: Martin O’Neill arrives at Villa Park on the day he is appointed as the new manager. Soon after, the club changes hands with Randy Lerner taking the reins from Doug Ellis.

text.headline: Top 6 finish
text.text: Villa enjoy a fantastic second term under O'Neill. Attendances soar to a 58-year high and the team are good value for a top six finish, beating Ajax in a showpiece clash at Villa Park in the UEFA Cup.

text.headline: Top 6 finish
text.text: Villa again finish sixth and compete in the UEFA Cup. Ashley Young is named PFA Young Player of the Year while on the downside, Martin Laursen is forced to retire because of a knee injury.

text.headline: Humble Beginnings
text.text: League Cup runners up

text.headline: FA Cup runners-up
text.text: Villa lose to Arsenal in the FA Cup final.
